1.verse: King David’s son Solomon was now the undisputed ruler of Israel, for the Lord his God had made him a powerful monarch.

2.verse: He summoned all the army officers and judges to Gibeon as well as all the political and religious leaders of Israel. He led them up the hill to the old Tabernacle* constructed by Moses, the Lord’s assistant, while he was in the wilderness.

3.verse: He summoned all the army officers and judges to Gibeon as well as all the political and religious leaders of Israel. He led them up the hill to the old Tabernacle* constructed by Moses, the Lord’s assistant, while he was in the wilderness.

4.verse: (There was a later Tabernacle in Jerusalem, built by King David for the Ark of God when he removed it from Kiriath-jearim.)

5.verse: The bronze altar made by Bezalel (son of Uri, son of Hur) still stood in front of the old Tabernacle, and now Solomon and those he had invited assembled themselves before it, as he sacrificed upon it 1,000 burnt offerings to the Lord.

6.verse: The bronze altar made by Bezalel (son of Uri, son of Hur) still stood in front of the old Tabernacle, and now Solomon and those he had invited assembled themselves before it, as he sacrificed upon it 1,000 burnt offerings to the Lord.

7.verse: That night God appeared to Solomon and told him, “Ask me for anything, and I will give it to you!”

8.verse: Solomon replied, “O God, you have been so kind and good to my father David, and now you have given me the kingdom—

9.verse: this is all I want! For you have fulfilled your promise to David my father and have made me king over a nation as full of people as the earth is full of dust!

10.verse: Now give me wisdom and knowledge to rule them properly, for who is able to govern by himself such a great nation as this one of yours?”

11.verse: God replied, “Because your greatest desire is to help your people, and you haven’t asked for personal wealth and honor, and you haven’t asked me to curse your enemies, and you haven’t asked for a long life, but for wisdom and knowledge to properly guide my people—

12.verse: yes, I am giving you the wisdom and knowledge you asked for! And I am also giving you riches, wealth, and honor such as no other king has ever had before you! And there will never again be so great a king in all the world!”

13.verse: Solomon then left the Tabernacle, returned down the hill, and went back to Jerusalem to rule Israel.

14.verse: He built up a huge force of 1,400 chariots and recruited 12,000 cavalry to guard the cities where the chariots were garaged, though some, of course, were stationed at Jerusalem near the king.

15.verse: During Solomon’s reign, silver and gold were as plentiful in Jerusalem as rocks on the road! And expensive cedar lumber was used like common sycamore!

16.verse: Solomon sent horse traders to Egypt to purchase entire herds at wholesale prices.

17.verse: At that time Egyptian chariots sold for $400 each and horses for $100, delivered at Jerusalem. Many of these were then resold to the kings of the Hittites and Syria.

1.verse: Solomon now decided that the time had come to build a temple for the Lord and a palace for himself.

2.verse: This required a force of 70,000 laborers, 80,000 stonecutters in the hills, and 3,600 foremen.

3.verse: Solomon sent an ambassador to King Hiram at Tyre, requesting shipments of cedar lumber such as Hiram had supplied to David when he was building his palace.

4.verse: “I am about to build a temple for the Lord my God,” Solomon told Hiram. “It will be a place where I can burn incense and sweet spices before God, and display the special sacrificial bread, and sacrifice burnt offerings each morning and evening, and on the Sabbaths, and at the new moon celebration and other regular festivals of the Lord our God. For God wants Israel always to celebrate these special occasions.

5.verse: It is going to be a wonderful temple because he is a great God, greater than any other.

6.verse: But who can ever build him a worthy home? Not even the highest heaven would be beautiful enough! And who am I to be allowed to build a temple for God? But it will be a place to worship him.

7.verse: “So send me skilled craftsmen—goldsmiths and silversmiths, brass and iron workers; and send me weavers to make purple, crimson, and blue cloth; and skilled engravers to work beside the craftsmen of Judah and Jerusalem who were selected by my father David.

8.verse: Also send me cedar trees, fir trees, and algum trees from the forests of Lebanon, for your men are without equal as lumbermen, and I will send my men to help them.

9.verse: An immense amount of lumber will be needed, for the temple I am going to build will be large and incredibly beautiful.

10.verse: As to the financial arrangements, I will pay your men 20,000 sacks of crushed wheat, 20,000 barrels of barley, 20,000 barrels of wine, and 20,000 barrels of olive oil.”

11.verse: King Hiram replied to King Solomon: “It is because the Lord loves his people that he has made you their king!

12.verse: Blessed be the Lord God of Israel who made the heavens and the earth and who has given to David such a wise, intelligent, and understanding son to build God’s Temple and a royal palace for himself.

13.verse: “I am sending you a master craftsman—my famous Huramabi! He is a brilliant man,

14.verse: the son of a Jewish woman from Dan in Israel; his father is from here in Tyre. He is a skillful goldsmith and silversmith, and also does exquisite work with brass and iron and knows all about stonework, carpentry, and weaving; and he is an expert in the dyeing of purple and blue linen and crimson cloth. He is an engraver besides, and an inventor! He will work with your craftsmen and those appointed by my lord David, your father.

15.verse: So send along the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine you mentioned,

16.verse: and we will begin cutting wood from the Lebanon mountains, as much as you need, and bring it to you in log floats across the sea to Joppa, and from there you can take them inland to Jerusalem.”

17.verse: Solomon now took a census of all foreigners in the country (just as his father David had done) and found that there were 153,600 of them.

18.verse: He indentured 70,000 as common laborers, 80,000 as loggers, and 3,600 as foremen.

1.verse: Finally the actual construction of the Temple began. Its location was in Jerusalem at the top of Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to Solomon’s father, King David, and where the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite had been. David had selected it as the site for the Temple.

2.verse: The actual construction began on the seventeenth day of April in the fourth year of King Solomon’s reign.

3.verse: The foundation was ninety feet long and thirty feet wide.

4.verse: A covered porch ran along the entire thirty-foot width of the Temple, with the inner walls and ceiling overlaid with pure gold! The roof was 180 feet high.

5.verse: The main part of the Temple was paneled with cypress wood, plated with pure gold, and engraved with palm trees and chains.

6.verse: Beautiful jewels were inlaid into the walls to add to the beauty; the gold, by the way, was of the best, from Parvaim.

7.verse: All the walls, beams, doors, and thresholds throughout the Temple were plated with gold, with Guardian Angels engraved on the walls.

8.verse: Within the Temple, at one end, was the most sacred room—the Holy of Holies—thirty feet square. This too was overlaid with the finest gold, valued at millions of dollars.

9.verse: Twenty-six-ounce gold nails were used. The upper rooms were also plated with pure gold.

10.verse: Within the innermost room, the Holy of Holies, Solomon placed two sculptured statues of Guardian Angels and plated them with gold.

11.verse: They stood on the floor facing the outer room, with wings stretched wing tip to wing tip across the room, from wall to wall.

12.verse: They stood on the floor facing the outer room, with wings stretched wing tip to wing tip across the room, from wall to wall.

13.verse: They stood on the floor facing the outer room, with wings stretched wing tip to wing tip across the room, from wall to wall.

14.verse: Across the entrance to this room he placed a veil of blue and crimson finespun linen, decorated with Guardian Angels.

15.verse: At the front of the Temple were two pillars 52½ feet high, topped by a 7½-foot capital flaring out to the roof.

16.verse: He made chains and placed them on top of the pillars, with 100 pomegranates attached to the chains.

17.verse: Then he set up the pillars at the front of the Temple, one on the right and the other on the left. And he gave them names: Jachin (the one on the right), and Boaz (the one on the left).

1.verse: He also made a bronze altar 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 15 feet high.

2.verse: Then he forged a huge round tank 15 feet across from rim to rim. The rim stood 7½ feet above the floor, and was 45 feet around.

3.verse: The tank was encircled at its base by two rows of gourd designs, cast as part of the tank.

4.verse: The tank stood on twelve metal oxen facing outward; three faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east.

5.verse: The walls of the tank were five inches thick, flaring out like the cup of a lily. It held 3,000 barrels of water.

6.verse: He also constructed ten vats for water to wash the offerings, five to the right of the huge tank and five to the left. The priests used the tank, and not the vats, for their own washing.

7.verse: Carefully following God’s instructions, he then cast ten gold lampstands and placed them in the Temple, five against each wall;

8.verse: he also built ten tables and placed five against each wall on the right and left. And he molded 100 solid gold bowls.

9.verse: Then he constructed a court for the priests, also the public court, and overlaid the doors of these courts with bronze.

10.verse: The huge tank was in the southeast corner of the outer room of the Temple.

11.verse: Huramabi also made the necessary pots, shovels, and basins for use in connection with the sacrifices. So at last he completed the work assigned to him by King Solomon:

This skillful craftsman, Huramabi, made all of the above-mentioned items for King Solomon using polished bronze.

19.verse: Solomon commanded that all of the furnishings of the Temple—the utensils, the altar, and the table for the Bread of the Presence must be made of gold;

20.verse: also the lamps and lampstands,

21.verse: the floral decorations, tongs,

22.verse: lamp snuffers, basins, spoons, and firepans—all were made of solid gold. Even the doorway of the Temple, the main door, and the inner doors to the Holy of Holies were overlaid with gold.

1.verse: So the Temple was finally finished. Then Solomon brought in the gifts dedicated to the Lord by his father, King David. They were stored in the Temple treasuries.

2.verse: Solomon now summoned to Jerusalem all of the leaders of Israel—the heads of the tribes and clans—for the ceremony of transferring the Ark from the Tabernacle in the City of David, also known as Zion, to its new home in the Temple.*

3.verse: This celebration took place in October at the annual Festival of Tabernacles.

4.verse: As the leaders of Israel watched, the Levites lifted the Ark and carried it out of the Tabernacle, along with all the other sacred vessels.

5.verse: As the leaders of Israel watched, the Levites lifted the Ark and carried it out of the Tabernacle, along with all the other sacred vessels.

6.verse: King Solomon and the others sacrificed sheep and oxen before the Ark in such numbers that no one tried to keep count!

7.verse: Then the priests carried the Ark into the inner room of the Temple—the Holy of Holies—and placed it beneath the wings of the Guardian Angels; their wings spread over the Ark and its carrying poles.

8.verse: Then the priests carried the Ark into the inner room of the Temple—the Holy of Holies—and placed it beneath the wings of the Guardian Angels; their wings spread over the Ark and its carrying poles.

9.verse: These carrying poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the outer room, but not from the outside doorway. The Ark is still there at the time of this writing.

10.verse: Nothing was in the Ark except the two stone tablets that Moses had put there at Mount Horeb, when the Lord made a covenant with the people of Israel as they were leaving Egypt.

And how the Levites were praising the Lord as the priests came out of the Holy of Holies! The singers were Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and all their sons and brothers, dressed in finespun linen robes and standing at the east side of the altar. The choir was accompanied by 120 priests who were trumpeters, while others played the cymbals, lyres, and harps.

1.verse: This is the prayer prayed by Solomon on that occasion: “The Lord has said that he would live in the thick darkness, But I have made a Temple for you, O Lord, to live in forever!”

2.verse: This is the prayer prayed by Solomon on that occasion: “The Lord has said that he would live in the thick darkness, But I have made a Temple for you, O Lord, to live in forever!”

3.verse: Then the king turned around to the people and they stood to receive his blessing:

4.verse: “Blessed be the Lord God of Israel,” he said to them, “the God who talked personally to my father David and has now fulfilled the promise he made to him. For he told him,

5.verse: ‘I have never before, since bringing my people from the land of Egypt, chosen a city anywhere in Israel as the location of my Temple where my name will be glorified; and never before have I chosen a king for my people Israel. But now I have chosen Jerusalem as that city, and David as that king.’

6.verse: ‘I have never before, since bringing my people from the land of Egypt, chosen a city anywhere in Israel as the location of my Temple where my name will be glorified; and never before have I chosen a king for my people Israel. But now I have chosen Jerusalem as that city, and David as that king.’

7.verse: “My father David wanted to build this Temple,

8.verse: but the Lord said not to. It was good to have the desire, the Lord told him,

9.verse: but he was not the one to build it: his son was chosen for that task.

10.verse: And now the Lord has done what he promised, for I have become king in my father’s place, and I have built the Temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel

11.verse: and placed the Ark there. And in the Ark is the Covenant between the Lord and his people Israel.”

12.verse: As he spoke, Solomon was standing before the people on a platform in the center of the outer court, in front of the altar of the Lord. The platform was made of bronze, 7½ feet square and 4½ feet high. Now, as all the people watched, he knelt down, reached out his arms toward heaven, and prayed this prayer:

13.verse: As he spoke, Solomon was standing before the people on a platform in the center of the outer court, in front of the altar of the Lord. The platform was made of bronze, 7½ feet square and 4½ feet high. Now, as all the people watched, he knelt down, reached out his arms toward heaven, and prayed this prayer:

14.verse: “O Lord God of Israel, there is no God like you in all of heaven and earth. You are the God who keeps his kind promises to all those who obey you and who are anxious to do your will.

15.verse: And you have kept your promise to my father David, as is evident today.

16.verse: And now, O God of Israel, carry out your further promise to him that ‘your descendants shall always reign over Israel if they will obey my laws as you have.’

17.verse: Yes, Lord God of Israel, please fulfill this promise too.

18.verse: But will God really live upon the earth with men? Why, even the heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain you—how much less this Temple I have built!

19.verse: “How I pray that you will heed my prayers, O Lord my God! Listen to my prayer that I am praying to you now!

20.verse: Look down with favor day and night upon this Temple—upon this place where you have said that you would put your name. May you always hear and answer the prayers I will pray to you as I face toward this place. Listen to my prayers and to those of your people Israel when they pray toward this Temple; yes, hear us from heaven, and when you hear, forgive.

21.verse: Look down with favor day and night upon this Temple—upon this place where you have said that you would put your name. May you always hear and answer the prayers I will pray to you as I face toward this place. Listen to my prayers and to those of your people Israel when they pray toward this Temple; yes, hear us from heaven, and when you hear, forgive.

22.verse: “Whenever someone commits a crime and is required to swear to his innocence before this altar,

23.verse: then hear from heaven and punish him if he is lying, or else declare him innocent.

24.verse: “If your people Israel are destroyed before their enemies because they have sinned against you, and if they turn to you and call themselves your people, and pray to you here in this Temple,

25.verse: then listen to them from heaven and forgive their sins and give them back this land you gave to their fathers.

26.verse: “When the skies are shut and there is no rain because of our sins, and then we pray toward this Temple and claim you as our God, and turn from our sins because you have punished us,

27.verse: then listen from heaven and forgive the sins of your people, and teach them what is right; and send rain upon this land that you have given to your people as their own property.

28.verse: “If there is a famine in the land, or plagues, or crop disease, or attacks of locusts or caterpillars, or if your people’s enemies are in the land besieging our cities—whatever the trouble is—

29.verse: listen to every individual’s prayer concerning his private sorrow, as well as all the public prayers.

30.verse: Hear from heaven where you live and forgive, and give each one whatever he deserves, for you know the hearts of all mankind.

31.verse: Then they will reverence you forever and will continually walk where you tell them to go.

32.verse: “And when foreigners hear of your power, and come from distant lands to worship your great name, and to pray toward this Temple,

33.verse: hear them from heaven where you live, and do what they request of you. Then all the peoples of the earth will hear of your fame and will reverence you, just as your people Israel do; and they too will know that this Temple I have built is truly yours.

34.verse: “If your people go out at your command to fight their enemies, and they pray toward this city of Jerusalem that you have chosen, and this Temple that I have built for your name,

35.verse: then hear their prayers from heaven and give them success.

36.verse: “If they sin against you (and who has never sinned?) and you become angry with them, and you let their enemies defeat them and take them away as captives to some foreign nation near or far;

37.verse: and if in that land of exile they turn to you again, and face toward this land you gave their fathers and this city and your Temple I have built, and plead with you with all their hearts to forgive them,

38.verse: and if in that land of exile they turn to you again, and face toward this land you gave their fathers and this city and your Temple I have built, and plead with you with all their hearts to forgive them,

39.verse: then hear from heaven where you live and help them, and forgive your people who have sinned against you.

40.verse: “Yes, O my God, be wide awake and attentive to all the prayers made to you in this place.

41.verse: And now, O Lord God, arise and enter this resting place of yours where the Ark of your strength has been placed. Let your priests, O Lord God, be clothed with salvation, and let your people rejoice in your kind deeds.

42.verse: O Lord God, do not ignore me—do not turn your face away from me, your anointed one. Oh, remember your love for David and your kindness to him.”

3.verse: All the people had been watching, and now they fell flat on the pavement and worshiped and thanked the Lord. “How good he is!” they exclaimed. “He is always so loving and kind.”

4.verse: Then the king and all the people dedicated the Temple by sacrificing burnt offerings to the Lord. King Solomon’s contribution for this purpose was 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep.

5.verse: Then the king and all the people dedicated the Temple by sacrificing burnt offerings to the Lord. King Solomon’s contribution for this purpose was 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep.

6.verse: The priests were standing at their posts of duty, and the Levites were playing their thanksgiving song, “His Loving-Kindness Is Forever,” using the musical instruments King David himself had made and had used to praise the Lord. Then, when the priests blew the trumpets, all the people stood again.

7.verse: Solomon consecrated the inner court of the Temple for use that day as a place of sacrifice because there were too many sacrifices for the bronze altar to accommodate.

8.verse: For the next seven days they celebrated the Tabernacle Festival, with large crowds coming in from all over Israel; they arrived from as far away as Hamath at one end of the country to the brook of Egypt at the other.

9.verse: A final religious service was held on the eighth day.

10.verse: Then on October 7 he sent the people home, joyful and happy because the Lord had been so good to David and Solomon and to his people Israel.

11.verse: So Solomon finished building the Temple as well as his own palace. He completed what he had planned to do.

12.verse: One night the Lord appeared to Solomon and told him, “I have heard your prayer and have chosen this Temple as the place where I want you to sacrifice to me.

13.verse: If I shut up the heavens so that there is no rain, or if I command the locust swarms to eat up all of your crops, or if I send an epidemic among you,

14.verse: then if my people will humble themselves and pray, and search for me, and turn from their wicked ways, I will hear them from heaven and forgive their sins and heal their land.

15.verse: I will listen, wide awake, to every prayer made in this place.

16.verse: For I have chosen this Temple and sanctified it to be my home forever; my eyes and my heart shall always be here.

17.verse: “As for yourself, if you follow me as your father David did,

18.verse: then I will see to it that you and your descendants will always be the kings of Israel;

19.verse: but if you don’t follow me, if you refuse the laws I have given you and worship idols,

20.verse: then I will destroy my people from this land of mine that I have given them, and this Temple shall be destroyed even though I have sanctified it for myself. Instead, I will make it a public horror and disgrace.

21.verse: Instead of its being famous, all who pass by will be incredulous. “‘Why has the Lord done such a terrible thing to this land and to this Temple?’ they will ask.

22.verse: “And the answer will be, ‘Because his people abandoned the Lord God of their fathers, the God who brought them out of the land of Egypt, and they worshiped other gods instead. That is why he has done all this to them.’”

1.verse: It was now twenty years since Solomon had become king, and the great building projects of the Lord’s Temple and his own royal palace were completed.

2.verse: He now turned his energies to rebuilding the cities that King Hiram of Tyre had given to him, and he relocated some of the people of Israel into them.

3.verse: It was at this time, too, that Solomon fought against the city of Hamath-zobah and conquered it.

4.verse: He built Tadmor in the desert and built cities in Hamath as supply centers.

5.verse: He fortified the cities of upper Beth-horon and lower Beth-horon, both being supply centers, building their walls and installing barred gates.

6.verse: He also built Baalath and other supply centers at this time and constructed cities where his chariots and horses were kept. He built to his heart’s desire in Jerusalem and Lebanon and throughout the entire realm.

7.verse: He began the practice that still continues of conscripting as slave laborers the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—the descendants of those nations that the Israelis had not completely wiped out.

8.verse: He began the practice that still continues of conscripting as slave laborers the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—the descendants of those nations that the Israelis had not completely wiped out.

9.verse: However, he didn’t make slaves of any of the Israeli citizens, but used them as soldiers, officers, charioteers, and cavalrymen;

10.verse: also, 250 of them were government officials who administered all public affairs.

11.verse: Solomon now moved his wife (she was Pharaoh’s daughter) from the City of David sector of Jerusalem to the new palace he had built for her. For he said, “She must not live in King David’s palace for the Ark of the Lord was there, and it is holy ground.”

12.verse: Then Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings to the Lord on the altar he had built in front of the porch of the Temple.

13.verse: The number of sacrifices differed from day to day in accordance with the instructions Moses had given; there were extra sacrifices on the Sabbaths, on new moon festivals, and at the three annual festivals—the Passover celebration, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Tabernacles.

14.verse: In assigning the priests to their posts of duty he followed the organizational chart prepared by his father David; he also assigned the Levites to their work of praise and of helping the priests in each day’s duties; and he assigned the gatekeepers to their gates.

15.verse: Solomon did not deviate in any way from David’s instructions concerning these matters and concerning the treasury personnel.

16.verse: Thus Solomon successfully completed the construction of the Temple.

17.verse: Then he went to the seaport towns of Ezion-geber and Eloth, in Edom, to launch a fleet presented to him by King Hiram. These ships, with King Hiram’s experienced crews working alongside Solomon’s men, went to Ophir and brought back to him several million dollars worth of gold on each trip!

1.verse: When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon’s fabled wisdom, she came to Jerusalem to test him with hard questions. A very great retinue of aides and servants accompanied her, including camel loads of spices, gold, and jewels.

2.verse: And Solomon answered all her problems. Nothing was hidden from him; he could explain everything to her.

3.verse: When she discovered how wise he really was, and how breathtaking the beauty of his palace,

4.verse: and how wonderful the food at his tables, and how many servants and aides he had, and when she saw their spectacular uniforms and his stewards in full regalia, and saw the size of the men in his bodyguard, she could scarcely believe it!

5.verse: Finally she exclaimed to the king, “Everything I heard about you in my own country is true!

6.verse: I didn’t believe it until I got here and saw it with my own eyes. Your wisdom is far greater than I could ever have imagined.

7.verse: What a privilege for these men of yours to stand here and listen to you talk!

8.verse: Blessed be the Lord your God! How he must love Israel to give them a just king like you! He wants them to be a great, strong nation forever.”

9.verse: She gave the king a gift of over a million dollars in gold, and great quantities of spices of incomparable quality, and many, many jewels.

10.verse: King Hiram’s and King Solomon’s crews brought gold from Ophir, also sandalwood and jewels.

11.verse: The king used the sandalwood to make terraced steps for the Temple and the palace and to construct harps and lyres for the choir. Never before had there been such beautiful instruments in all the land of Judah.

12.verse: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba gifts of the same value as she had brought to him, plus everything else she asked for! Then she and her retinue returned to their own land.

13.verse: Solomon received a quarter of a billion dollars worth of gold each year from the kings of Arabia and many other lands that paid annual tribute to him. In addition, there was a trade balance from the exports of his merchants.

14.verse: Solomon received a quarter of a billion dollars worth of gold each year from the kings of Arabia and many other lands that paid annual tribute to him. In addition, there was a trade balance from the exports of his merchants.

15.verse: He used some of the gold to make 200 large shields, each worth $100,000,

16.verse: and 300 smaller shields, each worth $50,000. The king placed these in the Forest of Lebanon Room in his palace.

17.verse: He also made a huge ivory throne overlaid with pure gold.

18.verse: It had six gold steps and a footstool of gold; also gold armrests, each flanked by a gold lion.

19.verse: Gold lions also stood at each side of each step. No other throne in all the world could be compared with it!

20.verse: All of King Solomon’s cups were solid gold, as were all the furnishings in the Forest of Lebanon Room. Silver was too cheap to count for much in those days!

21.verse: Every three years the king sent his ships to Tarshish, using sailors supplied by King Hiram, to bring back gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.

22.verse: So King Solomon was richer and wiser than any other king in all the earth.

23.verse: Kings from every nation came to visit him and to hear the wisdom God had put into his heart.

24.verse: Each brought him annual tribute of silver and gold bowls, clothing, armor, spices, horses, and mules.

25.verse: In addition, Solomon had 4,000 stalls of horses and chariots, and 12,000 cavalrymen stationed in the chariot cities as well as in Jerusalem to protect the king.

26.verse: He ruled over all kings and kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and as far away as the border of Egypt.

27.verse: He made silver become as plentiful in Jerusalem as stones in the road! And cedar was used as though it were common sycamore.

28.verse: Horses were brought to him from Egypt and other countries.

29.verse: The rest of Solomon’s biography is written in the history of Nathan the prophet and in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and also in the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam the son of Nebat.

30.verse: So Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all of Israel for forty years.

31.verse: Then he died and was buried in Jerusalem, and his son Rehoboam became the new king.

4.verse: “Your father was a hard master,” they said. “Be easier on us than he was, and we will let you be our king!”

5.verse: Rehoboam told them to return in three days for his decision.

6.verse: He discussed their demand with the old men who had counseled his father Solomon. “What shall I tell them?” he asked.

7.verse: “If you want to be their king,” they replied, “you will have to give them a favorable reply and treat them with kindness.”

8.verse: But he rejected their advice and asked the opinion of the young men who had grown up with him. “What do you fellows think I should do?” he asked. “Shall I be easier on them than my father was?”

10.verse: “No!” they replied. “Tell them, ‘If you think my father was hard on you, just wait and see what I’ll be like!’ Tell them, ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s loins!

11.verse: I am going to be tougher on you, not easier! My father used whips on you, but I’ll use scorpions!’”

12.verse: So when Jeroboam and the people returned in three days to hear King Rehoboam’s decision,

13.verse: he spoke roughly to them; for he refused the advice of the old men

14.verse: and followed the counsel of the younger ones. “My father gave you heavy burdens, but I will give you heavier!” he told them. “My father punished you with whips, but I will punish you with scorpions!”

15.verse: So the king turned down the people’s demands. (God caused him to do it in order to fulfill his prediction spoken to Jeroboam by Ahijah the Shilonite.)

16.verse: When the people realized what the king was saying, they turned their backs and deserted him. “Forget David and his dynasty!” they shouted angrily. “We’ll get someone else to be our king. Let Rehoboam rule his own tribe of Judah! Let’s go home!” So they did.

17.verse: The people of the tribe of Judah, however, remained loyal to Rehoboam.

18.verse: Afterwards, when King Rehoboam sent Hadoram to draft forced labor from the other tribes of Israel, the people stoned him to death. When this news reached King Rehoboam, he jumped into his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.

19.verse: And Israel has refused to be ruled by a descendant of David to this day.

1.verse: Upon arrival at Jerusalem, Rehoboam mobilized the armies of Judah and Benjamin, 180,000 strong, and declared war against the rest of Israel in an attempt to reunite the kingdom.

2.verse: But the Lord told Shemaiah the prophet,

3.verse: “Go and say to King Rehoboam of Judah, Solomon’s son, and to the people of Judah and of Benjamin:

4.verse: “‘The Lord says, Do not fight against your brothers. Go home, for I am behind their rebellion.’” So they obeyed the Lord and refused to fight against Jeroboam.

5.verse: Rehoboam stayed in Jerusalem and fortified these cities of Judah with walls and gates to protect himself: Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa, Beth-zur, Soco, Adullam, Gath, Mareshah, Ziph, Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah, Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron.

11.verse: He also rebuilt and strengthened the forts, and manned them with companies of soldiers under their officers, and stored them with food, olive oil, and wine.

12.verse: Shields and spears were placed in armories in every city as a further safety measure. For only Judah and Benjamin remained loyal to him.

13.verse: However, the priests and Levites from the other tribes now abandoned their homes and moved to Judah and Jerusalem, for King Jeroboam had fired them, telling them to stop being priests of the Lord.

15.verse: He had appointed other priests instead who encouraged the people to worship idols instead of God and to sacrifice to carved statues of goats and calves, which he placed on the hills.

16.verse: Laymen, too, from all over Israel began moving to Jerusalem where they could freely worship the Lord God of their fathers and sacrifice to him.

17.verse: This strengthened the kingdom of Judah, so King Rehoboam survived for three years without difficulty; for during those years there was an earnest effort to obey the Lord as King David and King Solomon had done.

18.verse: Rehoboam married his cousin Mahalath. She was the daughter of David’s son Jerimoth and of Abihail, the daughter of David’s brother Eliab.

19.verse: Three sons were born from this marriage—Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.

20.verse: Later he married Maacah, the daughter of Absalom. The children she bore him were Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.

21.verse: He loved Maacah more than any of his other wives and concubines (he had eighteen wives and sixty concubines—with twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters).

22.verse: Maacah’s son Abijah was his favorite, and he intended to make him the next king.

23.verse: He very wisely scattered his other sons in the fortified cities throughout the land of Judah and Benjamin, and gave them large allowances and arranged for them to have several wives apiece.

1.verse: But just when Rehoboam was at the height of his popularity and power he abandoned the Lord, and the people followed him in this sin.

2.verse: As a result, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem in the fifth year of King Rehoboam’s reign

3.verse: with 1,200 chariots, 60,000 cavalrymen and an unnumbered host of infantrymen—Egyptians, Libyans, Sukkiim, and Ethiopians.

4.verse: He quickly conquered Judah’s fortified cities and soon arrived at Jerusalem.

5.verse: The prophet Shemaiah now met with Rehoboam and the Judean leaders from every part of the nation (they had fled to Jerusalem for safety) and told them, “The Lord says, ‘You have forsaken me, so I have forsaken you and abandoned you to Shishak.’”

6.verse: Then the king and the leaders of Israel confessed their sins and exclaimed, “The Lord is right in doing this to us!”

7.verse: And when the Lord saw them humble themselves, he sent Shemaiah to tell them, “Because you have humbled yourselves, I will not completely destroy you; some will escape. I will not use Shishak to pour out my anger upon Jerusalem.

8.verse: But you must pay annual tribute to him. Then you will realize how much better it is to serve me than to serve him!”

9.verse: So King Shishak of Egypt conquered Jerusalem and took away all the treasures of the Temple and of the palace, also all of Solomon’s gold shields.

10.verse: King Rehoboam replaced them with bronze shields and committed them to the care of the captain of his bodyguard.

11.verse: Whenever the king went to the Temple, the guards would carry them and afterwards return them to the armory.

12.verse: When the king humbled himself, the Lord’s anger was turned aside and he didn’t send total destruction; in fact, even after Shishak’s invasion, the economy of Judah remained strong.

13.verse: King Rehoboam reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city God had chosen as his residence after considering all the other cities of Israel. He had become king at the age of forty-one, and his mother’s name was Naamah the Ammonitess.

14.verse: But he was an evil king, for he never did decide really to please the Lord.

15.verse: The complete biography of Rehoboam is recorded in the histories written by Shemaiah the prophet and by Iddo the seer and in The Genealogical Register. There were continual wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.

16.verse: When Rehoboam died he was buried in Jerusalem, and his son Abijah became the new king.

1.verse: Abijah became the new king of Judah in Jerusalem in the eighteenth year of the reign of King Jeroboam of Israel. He lasted three years. His mother’s name was Micaiah (daughter of Uriel of Gibeah). Early in his reign war broke out between Judah and Israel.

2.verse: Abijah became the new king of Judah in Jerusalem in the eighteenth year of the reign of King Jeroboam of Israel. He lasted three years. His mother’s name was Micaiah (daughter of Uriel of Gibeah). Early in his reign war broke out between Judah and Israel.

3.verse: Judah, led by King Abijah, fielded 400,000 seasoned warriors against twice as many Israeli troops—strong, courageous men led by King Jeroboam.

4.verse: When the army of Judah arrived at Mount Zemaraim, in the hill country of Ephraim, King Abijah shouted to King Jeroboam and the Israeli army:

5.verse: “Listen! Don’t you realize that the Lord God of Israel swore that David’s descendants would always be the kings of Israel?

6.verse: Your King Jeroboam is a mere servant of David’s son and was a traitor to his master.

7.verse: Then a whole gang of worthless rebels joined him, defying Solomon’s son Rehoboam, for he was young and frightened and couldn’t stand up to them.

8.verse: Do you really think you can defeat the kingdom of the Lord that is led by a descendant of David? Your army is twice as large as mine, but you are cursed with those gold calves you have with you that Jeroboam made for you—he calls them your gods!

9.verse: And you have driven away the priests of the Lord and the Levites and have appointed heathen priests instead. Just like the people of other lands, you accept as priests anybody who comes along with a young bullock and seven rams for consecration. Anyone at all can be a priest of these no-gods of yours!

10.verse: “But as for us, the Lord is our God and we have not forsaken him. Only the descendants of Aaron are our priests, and the Levites alone may help them in their work.

11.verse: They burn sacrifices to the Lord every morning and evening—burnt offerings and sweet incense; and they place the Bread of the Presence upon the holy table. The gold lampstand is lighted every night, for we are careful to follow the instructions of the Lord our God; but you have forsaken him.

12.verse: So you see, God is with us; he is our leader. His priests, trumpeting as they go, will lead us into battle against you. O people of Israel, do not fight against the Lord God of your fathers, for you will not succeed!”

13.verse: Meanwhile, Jeroboam had secretly sent part of his army around behind the men of Judah to ambush them; so Judah was surrounded, with the enemy before and behind them. Then they cried out to the Lord for mercy, and the priests blew the trumpets.

14.verse: Meanwhile, Jeroboam had secretly sent part of his army around behind the men of Judah to ambush them; so Judah was surrounded, with the enemy before and behind them. Then they cried out to the Lord for mercy, and the priests blew the trumpets.

15.verse: The men of Judah began to shout. And as they shouted, God used King Abijah and the men of Judah to turn the tide of battle against King Jeroboam and the army of Israel,

16.verse: The men of Judah began to shout. And as they shouted, God used King Abijah and the men of Judah to turn the tide of battle against King Jeroboam and the army of Israel,

17.verse: and they slaughtered 500,000 elite troops of Israel that day.

18.verse: So Judah, depending upon the Lord God of their fathers, defeated Israel, and chased King Jeroboam’s troops, and captured some of his cities—Bethel, Jeshanah, Ephron, and their suburbs.

19.verse: So Judah, depending upon the Lord God of their fathers, defeated Israel, and chased King Jeroboam’s troops, and captured some of his cities—Bethel, Jeshanah, Ephron, and their suburbs.

20.verse: King Jeroboam of Israel never regained his power during Abijah’s lifetime, and eventually the Lord struck him and he died.

21.verse: Meanwhile, King Abijah of Judah became very strong. He married fourteen wives and had twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.

22.verse: His complete biography and speeches are recorded in the prophet Iddo’s History of Judah.

1.verse: King Abijah was buried in Jerusalem. Then his son Asa became the new king of Judah, and there was peace in the land for the first ten years of his reign,

2.verse: for Asa was careful to obey the Lord his God.

3.verse: He demolished the heathen altars on the hills, and broke down the obelisks, and chopped down the shameful Asherim idols,

4.verse: and demanded that the entire nation obey the commandments of the Lord God of their ancestors.

5.verse: Also, he removed the sun images from the hills and the incense altars from every one of Judah’s cities. That is why God gave his kingdom peace.

6.verse: This made it possible for him to build walled cities throughout Judah.

7.verse: “Now is the time to do it, while the Lord is blessing us with peace because of our obedience to him,” he told his people. “Let us build and fortify cities now, with walls, towers, gates, and bars.” So they went ahead with these projects very successfully.

8.verse: King Asa’s Judean army was 300,000 strong, equipped with light shields and spears. His army of Benjaminites numbered 280,000, armed with large shields and bows. Both armies were composed of well-trained, brave men.

9.verse: But now he was attacked by an army of 1,000,000 troops from Ethiopia with 300 chariots, under the leadership of General Zerah. They advanced to the city of Mareshah, in the valley of Zephathah, and King Asa sent his troops to battle with them there.

10.verse: But now he was attacked by an army of 1,000,000 troops from Ethiopia with 300 chariots, under the leadership of General Zerah. They advanced to the city of Mareshah, in the valley of Zephathah, and King Asa sent his troops to battle with them there.

11.verse: “O Lord,” he cried out to God, “no one else can help us! Here we are, powerless against this mighty army. Oh, help us, Lord our God! For we trust in you alone to rescue us, and in your name we attack this vast horde. Don’t let mere men defeat you!”

12.verse: Then the Lord defeated the Ethiopians, and Asa and the army of Judah triumphed as the Ethiopians fled.

13.verse: They chased them as far as Gerar, and the entire Ethiopian army was wiped out so that not one man remained; for the Lord and his army destroyed them all. Then the army of Judah carried off vast quantities of plunder.

14.verse: While they were at Gerar they attacked all the cities in that area, and terror from the Lord came upon the residents. As a result, additional vast quantities of plunder were collected from these cities too.

15.verse: They not only plundered the cities but destroyed the cattle tents and captured great herds of sheep and camels before finally returning to Jerusalem.

1.verse: Then the Spirit of God came upon Azariah (son of Oded),

2.verse: and he went out to meet King Asa as he was returning from the battle. “Listen to me, Asa! Listen, armies of Judah and Benjamin!” he shouted. “The Lord will stay with you as long as you stay with him! Whenever you look for him, you will find him. But if you forsake him, he will forsake you.

3.verse: For a long time now, over in Israel, the people haven’t worshiped the true God and have not had a true priest to teach them. They have lived without God’s laws.

4.verse: But whenever they have turned again to the Lord God of Israel in their distress and searched for him he has helped them.

5.verse: In their times of rebellion against God there was no peace. Problems troubled the nation on every hand. Crime was on the increase everywhere.

6.verse: There were external wars and internal fighting of city against city, for God was plaguing them with all sorts of trouble.

7.verse: But you men of Judah, keep up the good work and don’t get discouraged, for you will be rewarded.”

8.verse: When King Asa heard this message from God, he took courage and destroyed all the idols in the land of Judah and Benjamin and in the cities he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim, and he rebuilt the altar of the Lord in front of the Temple.

9.verse: Then he summoned all the people of Judah and Benjamin and the immigrants from Israel (for many had come from the territories of Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon in Israel when they saw that the Lord God was with King Asa).

10.verse: They all came to Jerusalem in June of the fifteenth year of King Asa’s reign

11.verse: and sacrificed to the Lord seven hundred oxen and seven thousand sheep—it was part of the plunder they had captured in the battle.

12.verse: Then they entered into a contract to worship only the Lord God of their fathers

13.verse: and agreed that anyone who refused to do this must die—whether old or young, man or woman.

14.verse: They shouted out their oath of loyalty to God with trumpets blaring and horns sounding.

15.verse: All were happy for this covenant with God, for they had entered into it with all their hearts and wills and wanted him above everything else, and they found him! And he gave them peace throughout the nation.

16.verse: King Asa even removed his mother Maacah from being the queen mother because she made an Asherah idol; he cut down the idol and crushed and burned it at Kidron Brook.

17.verse: Over in Israel the idol-temples were not removed. But here in Judah and Benjamin the heart of King Asa was perfect before God throughout his lifetime.

18.verse: He brought back into the Temple the silver and gold bowls that he and his father had dedicated to the Lord.

19.verse: So there was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of King Asa’s reign.

1.verse: In the thirty-sixth year of King Asa’s reign, King Baasha of Israel declared war on him and built the fortress of Ramah in order to control the road to Judah.

2.verse: Asa’s response was to take the silver and gold from the Temple and from the palace, and to send it to King Ben-hadad of Syria at Damascus with this message:

3.verse: “Let us renew the mutual security pact that there was between your father and my father. See, here is silver and gold to induce you to break your alliance with King Baasha of Israel, so that he will leave me alone.”

4.verse: Ben-hadad agreed to King Asa’s request and mobilized his armies to attack Israel. They destroyed the cities of Ijon, Dan, Abel-maim and all of the supply centers in Naphtali.

5.verse: As soon as King Baasha of Israel heard what was happening, he discontinued building Ramah and gave up his plan to attack Judah.

6.verse: Then King Asa and the people of Judah went out to Ramah and carried away the building stones and timbers and used them to build Geba and Mizpah instead.

7.verse: About that time the prophet Hanani came to King Asa and told him, “Because you have put your trust in the king of Syria instead of in the Lord your God, the army of the king of Syria has escaped from you.

8.verse: Don’t you remember what happened to the Ethiopians and Libyans and their vast army, with all of their chariots and cavalrymen? But you relied then on the Lord, and he delivered them all into your hand.

9.verse: For the eyes of the Lord search back and forth across the whole earth, looking for people whose hearts are perfect toward him, so that he can show his great power in helping them. What a fool you have been! From now on you shall have wars.”

10.verse: Asa was so angry with the prophet for saying this that he threw him into jail. And Asa oppressed all the people at that time.

11.verse: The rest of the biography of Asa is written in The Annals of the Kings of Israel and Judah.

12.verse: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa became seriously diseased in his feet, but he didn’t go to the Lord with the problem but to the doctors.

13.verse: So he died in the forty-first year of his reign and was buried in his own vault that he had hewn out for himself in Jerusalem. He was laid on a bed perfumed with sweet spices and ointments, and his people made a very great burning of incense for him at his funeral.

14.verse: So he died in the forty-first year of his reign and was buried in his own vault that he had hewn out for himself in Jerusalem. He was laid on a bed perfumed with sweet spices and ointments, and his people made a very great burning of incense for him at his funeral.

1.verse: Then his son Jehoshaphat became the king and mobilized for war against Israel.

2.verse: He placed garrisons in all of the fortified cities of Judah, in various other places throughout the country, and in the cities of Ephraim that his father had conquered.

3.verse: The Lord was with Jehoshaphat because he followed in the good footsteps of his father’s early years and did not worship idols.

4.verse: He obeyed the commandments of his father’s God—quite unlike the people across the border in the land of Israel.

5.verse: So the Lord strengthened his position as king of Judah. All the people of Judah cooperated by paying their taxes, so he became very wealthy as well as being very popular.

6.verse: He boldly followed the paths of God—even knocking down the heathen altars on the hills and destroying the Asherim idols.

7.verse: In the third year of his reign he began a nationwide religious education program. He sent out top government officials as teachers in all the cities of Judah. These men included Ben-hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah. He also used the Levites for this purpose, including Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tobadonijah; also the priests, Elishama and Jehoram. 10.verse: Then the fear of the Lord fell upon all the surrounding kingdoms so that none of them declared war on King Jehoshaphat.

11.verse: Even some of the Philistines brought him presents and annual tribute, and the Arabs donated 7,700 rams and 7,700 male goats.

12.verse: So Jehoshaphat became very strong and built fortresses and supply cities throughout Judah.

13.verse: His public works program was also extensive, and he had a huge army stationed at Jerusalem, his capital.

14.verse: Three hundred thousand Judean troops were there under General Adnah. Next in command was Jehohanan with an army of 280,000 men.

15.verse: Three hundred thousand Judean troops were there under General Adnah. Next in command was Jehohanan with an army of 280,000 men.

16.verse: Next was Amasiah (son of Zichri), a man of unusual piety, with 200,000 troops.

17.verse: Benjamin supplied 200,000 men equipped with bows and shields under the command of Eliada, a great general.

18.verse: His second in command was Jehozabad, with 180,000 trained men.

19.verse: These were the troops in Jerusalem in addition to those placed by the king in the fortified cities throughout the nation.

1.verse: But rich, popular King Jehoshaphat of Judah made a marriage alliance for his son with the daughter of* King Ahab of Israel.

2.verse: A few years later he went down to Samaria to visit King Ahab, and King Ahab gave a great party for him and his aides, butchering great numbers of sheep and oxen for the feast. Then he asked King Jehoshaphat to join forces with him against Ramoth-gilead.

3.verse: “Why, of course!” King Jehoshaphat replied. “I’m with you all the way. My troops are at your command!
